Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Standard berry and cherry aromas set up a fresh, fairly balanced and medium-weight palate with raspberry, red plum and oak flavors on the back end. It's mild on the finish, with snappy acidity that causes shortness.
Name: Dragonia 2009 Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Description: This is light in color and strikes the right strawberry tones. It's big and tannic, with weight and warmth on the finish.
Name: Lorenzi Estate 2009 Reserve Grenache (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Dark, meaty and ripe, the bouqiet has a strong wave of herb and carob notes. It feels grabby almost to the point of cloying, with heavily oaked flavors of roasted black fruit and milk chocolate. This is oak dominated, but full and chocolaty.
Name: Pagos Familia Langa 2009 Real de Aragon Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This brings light flavors of leaf and hard cherry candy, with a hint of cola.After its quick start, the wine tails off gently.
Name: Maryhill 2009 Proprietor's Reserve Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This is dark in color, with pushy aromas of wild field, prune and vinegar. Wide, chunky and heavy, it has flavors of black fruit, mint and green herb. It's full but soft on the finish, with pruny accents.
Name: Lelia 2010 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Stalky and sweet smelling, this has aromas of beets and rhubarb pie. The palate offers weight, depth and a firm feel, with sweet berry flavors that come with herb and mint accents. It's warm on the finish, with length.
Name: Almez 2009 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Floral and fruity smelling, this also has notes of dry earth and asphalt. It feels tangy and tomatoey, with saucy flavors of red cherry, tomato and herbs. The finish is herbal, with flavors of oregano and rosemary amplified by zingy acidity.
Name: Ignacio Marín 2010 Duque de Medina Tinto Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: With aromas of milk-chocolate-covered cherries and forced oak, this smells overtly sweet and candied. This feels choppy and juicy, with red fruit flavors and buttery oak in the background. It turns sweeter and more buttery on the finish, but doesn't offer much complexity.
Name: Gabarda 2008 Reserva Old Vine Red (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This is lightly baked and sweet on the nose, with a hint of plastic and raisin as the bouquet opens. It feels fresh and a bit sharp, with tangy red-plum and currant flavors followed by bland oak. The finish is tart and acidic.
Designation: Duque de Medina Crianza Old Vine
Name: Ignacio Marín 2009 Duque de Medina Crianza Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Fresh on the nose, with red cherry and apple skin aromas. This feels rather sharp and acidic, with flavors of tart cherry pie and red plum.
Name: Aletta 2010 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Burnt and gritty smelling, with rubbery, meaty berry aromas that turn candied and herbal with airing. This feels hollow, with roasted, stalky flavors and buttery young oak. It's grabby on the finish.
Name: Solar de Urbezo 2010 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Terra Alta, Catalonia, Spain
Description: This smells of latex and cinnamon. On the palate it's light and lean, with dilute flavors of cherry pie and unusual Middle Eastern spice. Grating and acidic on the finish.
Name: Jordi Miró 2010 Maceració Carbónica Garnatxa Negra Garnacha (Terra Alta)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Murky and stewy smelling, with no vitality and overt green accents. It's a bit heavy in feel, with salsa-like flavors of tomato, tomatillo, chili pepper and herbs.
Designation: Duque de Medina Reserva Old Vine
Name: Ignacio Marín 2008 Duque de Medina Reserva Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: Full-bodied and lush in style, with aromas of cherries and spice. On the palate, it delivers waves of fresh fruit and hints of cocoa, but also enough complexity to hold your interest before finishing on a long, mouthwatering note. Drink now–2016.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2008 Romas Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: What a wine. It tries to intimidate. At first, by its bottle size and alcohol level, but in the glass this 100% Garnacha is like a purring kitten—well a purring 20-pound Maine Coon cat, joyous in its pretty red fruit, and its earthy, meaty, vanilla and cinnamon toast range of goodness. All lush, Twisted Oak's Torcido is, like a retro soap opera, brave and beautiful.
Name: Twisted Oak 2009 Torcido Garnacha (Calaveras County)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: Depending on the vintage, any of Clarendon Hills' Grenaches can excel. In 2008, Kangarilla offers a lovely texture somewhere between fine silt and silk. Brandied cherries give an impression of warmth, balanced by herbal nuances and reined in by that fine-grained texture. Drink now–2015.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2008 Kangarilla Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: Featuring some dusty tannins on the finish, this is fairly structured for Aussie Grenache. Dried herbs and dried cherries are balanced by hints of dusty earth on the long finish. Drink 2013–2017.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2008 Blewitt Springs Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: This ripe Grenache is full-bodied and fruit-driven, but seems to have the stuffing to last at least 3–4 years. Cherry-berry flavors are punched up by herb and spice shadings that linger on the finish.
Name: Chapel Hill 2008 Bush Vine Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Dried leaf and cherry tobacco scents highlight this well-made Grenache. It includes just a whiff or two of the classic funk, but the rich black-cherry fruit is the real star, well-ripened and leading into a clean, lingering finish.
Name: Smasne Cellars 2009 Upland Vineyard Grenache (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: A tremendous Grenache from the Foothills, estate grown from Beaucastel budwood and let to develop slowly, this wine has acres to go before it sleeps. Still superdense and dark with fruity plum and anise predominating, it'll grow old with tenderness and grace.
Name: Cedarville 2009 Estate Bottled Grenache (El Dorado)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is an instantly loveable Grenache, bursting with ripe, sweet raspberries and cherries. Young and fresh, it's like sucking on a really good candy; then it finishes with a flourish of toast and mocha.
Name: Trio Vintners 2009 Far Away Vineyard Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Dark and smoky, this rather heavy-set Grenache has a chocolaty note from start to finish. The raspberry and black cherry fruit is tight but substantial, and the barrel aging—21 months in 20% new French oak—handled just right.
Name: Ott & Murphy 2009 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Clements Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Description: Very savory and herbal, this is one of Bokisch's bigger-bodied reds, still bright with strawberry, cherry, even cranberry and earthy flavors and packing a powerful, Rioja-type finish at the end.
Name: Bokisch 2009 Terra Alta Vineyard Garnacha (Clements Hills)

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is the first Grenache from Nefarious, and it's a beauty. Sourced from the Upland vineyard in the tiny Snipes Mountain AVA, it is bursting with pure, sweet fruit flavors, tart and lip-smackingly juicy. A subtle minerality with a hint of wet cement gives it tannic authority, while the aging in once-filled French oak barrels adds a touch of baking spices.
Name: Nefarious 2009 Grenache (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: In previous years Sierra Vista used its Grenache only as a blender but no more. This bottling shows its rightful place as a standalone, savory and very herbal with meat and baking spices aplenty and all the bright, clean red raspberry and strawberry fruit a subtle Grenache can offer, all at a low alcohol level.
Name: Sierra Vista 2009 Grenache (El Dorado)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A huge load with sophistication and style to go with tons of raw power. Tobacco, balsam wood and pure blackberry aromas are stylish and enticing. Shows body and structure on the palate along with black fruit, mocha, chocolate and toast flavors. Long and heavenly on the finish. Drink now through 2015.
Name: Alto Moncayo 2008 Aquilon Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Gets out of the blocks with massive cedar, balsamic, tobacco and bold berry aromas. It's super rich and thorough in the mouth, with excellent balance for a 16% ABV Garnacha. Flavors of roasted black fruits, coconut, coffee and mocha are giant; finishes even more oaky and barrel-driven, with vanilla, coconut and toast flavors. Drink now through the winter of 2013.
Name: Alto Moncayo 2008 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Smoky, peppery and tight on the nose, with leather and dark fruit aromas. The palate is chewy and dense, with syrupy richness and sweet flavors of ripe blackberry, toast, coffee, mocha and chocolate. Big and round on the finish; rock solid and seriously built. Drink now through 2013.
Name: Alto Moncayo 2008 Veraton Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Pretty and forward, this lovely wine bursts forth with raspberry and sweet cherry tomato fruit flavors. A slight mintiness can also be detected, all within the context of an impeccably balanced, firm, pleasingly acidic young red wine.
Name: Maison Bleue 2009 Boushey Vineyard Le Midi Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: From the (Cayuse) Armada Vineyard, the blend includes 8% Syrah. Very floral, with lovely scents of lily and spice. It's all fruit, with no new wood, and some whole cluster flavors of bark and stem. All nicely integrated and subtle, adding texture and detail. There is a streak of balsamic, and tart berry fruit flavors with a powerful, peppery, earthy component from the vineyard.
Name: K Vintners 2008 The Boy Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Heavy doses of char, rubber, graphite and hickory dance with black fruit aromas. Tastes big, rich, resiny and lemony, with a ton of barrel action forcing up chocolate, resin and dark spice flavors. Warm and long on the finish, with power to spare. 100% Garnacha.
Name: Borsao 2009 Tres Picos Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A powerful specimen that plows straight ahead on the bouquet, dealing out whiffs of rubber, smoke and hickory along the way. Meaty feeling and deep, with roasted blackberry, woodspice and bitter chocolate flavors. Dark and chocolaty on the finish, with a note of bacon.
Name: Pagos del Moncayo 2009 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Savory and exotic on the nose, with blueberry and cardamom. The palate strikes hard with tannic clamp and reduction. Flavors run lemony and herbal, with star anise and cardamom mixing with berry fruit. Clacky and tight on the finish, but serious and complex. 350 cases made; drink now through 2012.
Name: Pasolasmonjas 2008 Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Heathcote, Victoria, Australia
Description: Minty and raisiny on the nose, with Port-like elements of dried fruit and high (15.0%) alcohol. Still, it shows the variety's trademark delicate structure and silky texture.
Name: Jasper Hill 2007 Cornella Vineyard Grenache (Heathcote)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: An unusual and exotic bouquet is the greeting; it smells like Middle Eastern spice, blueberry and cinnamon. Runs a bit flat and syrupy in the mouth, with raisin, stewed plum and spicy flavors. Fig and carob flavors define the finish, which is thick and soft.
Name: Coto de Hayas 2007 Fagus Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Starts out with scratchy, dusty, red fruit aromas. The first impression in the mouth is of shrill acidity, but as it evolves and expands that acidity helps prop up cherry and red plum flavors. Cleansing and crisp on the finish, with structure and zest.
Designation: El Chaparral de Vega Sindoa Old Vines
Name: Vega Sindoa 2009 El Chaparral de Vega Sindoa Old Vines Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A touch stemmy on the nose, with herbal aromas and a hint of brine. Round on the palate, with a good mouthfeel and herbal berry flavors. Shows bounce and heat on the finish, but also a final note of green.
Name: Castillo de Monjardin 2009 La Cantera Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Description: It is entirely possible that this wine was simply released way too soon and thus tasted too early, but as is tannic and thin, a showcase for warm-weather Grenache without the variety's classic fruitiness and balance.
Name: Jeriko 2010 Jeriko Vineyards Grenache (Mendocino)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: A grapey wine, thin and watery, with just a hint of raspberry soda pop and coffee grounds.
Name: Reustle 2009 Grenache (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Effusively fruity, bursting with ripe scents and flavors of berries and cherries. There is an interesting underlayer of earthy peat moss, just as an accent. The concentration is exceptional, dense and layered and constantly reinventing itself as it rolls through a spicy, herbal finish.
Name: Cayuse 2008 God Only Knows Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: A delicious bottle, focused and deep, with plush cherry/berry fruit. It's crisply defined and nicely balanced, framing its substantial alcohol with just a hint of barrel toast (only about one sixth was aged in new oak).
Name: Dusted Valley 2009 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Montsant, Catalonia, Spain
Description: A single-vineyard Garnacha that's ripe and sultry. There's earth and oak on the mineral-tinged nose and then smooth flavors of blackberry, baked plum and spice. Feels soft and mature for Garnacha, and therein lies the secret of Montsant: The better wines (like this one) have a pleasant, friendly quality to them.
Name: Capçanes 2008 Cabrida Garnacha (Montsant)

Appellation: Montsant, Catalonia, Spain
Description: Smoky and dry for starters, then crisp in the mouth, with bright red fruit flavors of cherry and plum. Picks up oak, heat and sweetness on the finish, but overall this is exactly the type of flavor-packed red wine most people want. Grenache with 15% Syrah.
Name: Capçanes 2009 Mas Donis Barrica Garnacha (Montsant)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Plump and juicy flavors of bramble, red currant and raspberry lead into a smooth, satisfying middle with a streak of caramel running right through it. Excellent flavor and persistence for such a young wine. Just a little thin as it fades.
Name: Novelty Hill 2008 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: This Sierra Foothills Grenache Noir, as it's labeled, has an intense, grapey nose, its taste silky, smooth and juicy with decent length and texture, though the wine could use more layers. Estate-grown, this is an interesting producer of Rhône varieties in El Dorado, this wine blended with 8% Mourvedre and 1% Petite Sirah.
Name: Holly's Hill 2009 Estate Grenache (El Dorado)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Big, black and alive in the glass, with earth and black fruit aromas. The mouth is lively and pure, with blackberry and red plum flavors covering both the dark and red fruit bases. Grabby and long on the finish; very likable value-priced Grenache.
Name: Borsao 2010 Garnacha Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Floral and fresh smelling, with rosy notes, blueberry and nary any funk, leather or earth. Vibrant and juicy in the mouth, with boysenberry and plum flavors that set up a fruity, clean finish. Brighter, smoother and easier going than the 2009.
Name: Evodia 2010 Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Minty, pointy oak aromas jump out at you, followed by pepper, leather, spice and herbal berry scents. Tight and structured in the mouth, with black plum and ripe berry flavors. Turns oaky and hot on the finish, with vanilla and pepper flavors. A little fiery but the real deal for Calatayud.
Name: Las Rocas de San Alejandro 2008 Vinas Viejas Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This perennial Best Buy is once again rock solid. Fresh berry fruit and compote aromas make for a good bouquet. There's no shortage of acidity, so the palate is jumpy and lively, with crisp, almost tart raspberry and plum flavors. Structured and forward; hamburgers and pizza wine par excellence.
Name: Borsao 2010 Monte Oton Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This Garnacha is another from the Borsao operations, and it's clean with plenty of black fruit on the nose and palate. Juicy, tight, forward stuff with a dark and peppery finish. A little raw and pointy, so drink with salami, a burger or skirt steak.
Name: Borsao 2010 Viña Borgia Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Earthy tobacco and natural warmth provide for a good nose. It's briary smelling as well, with racy cherry and plum flavors. Shows some heat from 15% alcohol, but for $9 wine it packs a lot power and flavor. Unmistakable Garnacha that reflects sunny environs.
Name: Evodia 2009 Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rubbery and dark on the nose, with lots of black plum and cherry to ponder. The palate is firm and balanced, with round, rubbery, roasted plum and dark berry flavors. Full, nice and long enough on the finish to keep you involved.
Name: Tres Ojos 2009 Unfiltered Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Mint and milk chocolate are the lead aromas, followed by cherry and herbal notes. The wine is basic, fresh and fruity, with choppy tannins, heat and lively red berry flavors with citrus undertones. Runs a bit rough and heady.
Name: El Escocés Volante 2009 La Multa Old Vine Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Mineral and leather aromas are a combination of the wine's rocky soil origins and heat and dryness from 15.2% alcohol. Evolves in the glass, going from tasting spicy/earthy to medicinal plum and berry. Finishes round, sweet, hot, herbal and syrupy.
Name: Las Rocas de San Alejandro 2009 Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Lightly herbal and briary smelling, with solid berry aromas. The palate is thorough and chewy, with herbal plum and berry flavors in front of a tasty, juicy finish that's medium in length and doesn't bite down.
Name: Bodegas la Aldea 2009 La Gardea Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Pointy on the nose, with modest fruit aromas suggestive of raspberry. A bit astringent across the palate, with red plum flavors that hit hard then fade fast, leaving bitterness akin to espresso. A crisp, juicy, tight style.
Name: Bodegas Aragonesas 2010 Viña Temprana Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Herbal up front, with pine aromas in addition to berry and plum. The palate is tannic and kind of gritty feeling, with medicinal cherry and candied berry flavors. Finishes sweet, with some burn.
Name: Sierra de Viento 2008 Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Salmon colored, with somewhat flat aromas of peach and sweet melon. Sweet on the palate, with weight and thickness along with cantaloupe and a candied aftertaste. Finishes chunky and flat; tasted twice with inconsistent findings. This note reflects the better bottle.
Name: Ochoa 2010 Rosado Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Rhône Valley, France
Description: Full bodied and concentrated, with a long, chewy finish, this wine gets points for being complex as well. It's plummy yet savory, with touches of braised beef, coffee and black olive. Drink 2013–2023.
Name: Tardieu-Laurent 2007 Cuvée Spéciale Grenache (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: This is plenty ripe, with alcohol just under 15%. Fruit flavors are a little over the top, getting into pruney, or at least a cooked, compote character. But you'll find berries galore, the acidity to balance and a streak of bark in the tannins.
Name: J. Scott Cellars 2009 Grenache (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Montsant, Catalonia, Spain
Description: A bit hard and leathery smelling, but there's enough cedar and smoky darkness to the nose that it invites you in. The palate is tight and drying, with earthy, slightly herbal flavors of spiced red berry. Short on fruit come finishing time but showing length, juicy acidity and structure.
Name: Gran Vinaio 2007 Grenache (Montsant)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Among $8 reds this is really good. The nose is roasted and jammy, and it deepens and cleans up with airing. The palate is full, chunky and offers proper balance, while the flavors are plummy and deep, with a touch of raisin and rubber. Solid on the finish, with grapy lasting flavors.
Name: Veraz 2008 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Aromas of sweet black cherry and dark plum form a good bouquet. The palate has smack and acidic bite, but the flavors are forward and clean, with a focus on plum and black cherry. Finishes full and long, with licorice as well as leftover acidity.
Name: Granate 2008 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Tire rubber, heat and funky, oak-based spice aromas are ominous and foretelling. The palate on this Garnacha is creamy and feels sticky, while the flavors are sugary and emphasize vanilla and marshmallow over clean fruit. Flaccid on the finish, with candied flavors.
Name: Coto de Hayas 2008 Fagus Selección Especial Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: As fine a Grenache as I have yet tasted from Washington State. The aching purity of the fruit, married to the density, focus and minerality, is breathtaking.
Name: Maison Bleue 2009 Upland Vineyard La Montagnette Grenache (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: Rioja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A big, dark, modern wine with lemon and shoe polish on the nose but also rich black fruit aromas. The palate is both elegant and beefy, with lush blackberry and copious spice and chocolate flavors. Finishes full, mossy, rich and slightly herbal. A big success for varietal Rioja Grenache; drink now through 2012.
Name: Valserrano 2005 Monovarietales  (Rioja)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rich, warm, earthy and fully oaked, with mocha, molasses, blackberry and bacon aromas. The palate is huge but balanced, with clear, ripe black fruit, caramel and vanilla flavors. Modern and chunky but with flow and character; a winner for the price, with a toasty, mocha-driven finish.
Name: Bodegas Ateca 2009 Atteca Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Clean and fresh, this pure varietal Grenache captures the fruit nicely. Aged in neutral French oak for 15 months, it has smoothed out but shows no barrel spice at all. It's fruit, acid and crisp tannins, all in good proportion.
Name: Tertulia 2008 Lonesome Spring Ranch Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Almansa, Central Spain, Spain
Description: A little foxy at first, with lively, forward aromas of herbs, bramble, wild berry and black cherry. Doesn't take long in the glass to show its qualities, which include structure and plenty of fruit, herbs, pepper and dry spice on the palate. A voluminous, interesting Garnacha to slot into the everyday category.
Name: Higueruela 2009 Garnacha (Almansa)

Appellation: Almansa, Central Spain, Spain
Description: This colorfully packaged wine screams “concept export,” but what's in the bottle holds up to scrutiny. There's above-average cherry/berry aromas and then a full palate with popping acidity pushing lightly herbal plum and berry flavors. A well-made Garnacha from 20-year-old vineyards.
Name: Santa Quiteria 2009 BT Bodega Tintoralba Garnacha (Almansa)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Pointed and fresh on the nose despite a whopping and seemingly heavy 15.5% alcohol level. Given its weight class, sweetness on the bouquet and palate are not unexpected; flavors run toward candied cherry and raspberry, and as a whole it's all about sweet, bouncy red fruit and friendliness.
Name: Retorno 2009 Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Young, scratchy and sweet on the nose, but overall it's a good taste of easygoing Garnacha. Flavors are sweet and plummy, with blackberry and a touch of creamy vanilla. Finishes candied and thick, with a soft, sweet, short finish.
Name: Montgó 2009 Picos del Montgó Old Vines Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Description: A delicious Grenache sourced from Mendocino's Eaglepoint Vineyards, a high-elevation, cool-climate site with a peppery opening note that extends itself through dense chewy tannins and the bright fruitiness and inviting aromatics we all love about Grenache. A very nice bottle of wine with great backbone and depth that should age another 5–10 years.
Name: Stonehedge 2007 Terroir Select Grenache (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Rich, round and fruity, this substantial Grenache demonstrates the potential for this grape in Washington. Though winter hardiness can be a problem, in years such as this, where it ripens perfectly, the vines deliver a juicy, full-bodied wine brimming with cherry and brambly berry flavors. Here it has a light dusting of chocolate from aging in mostly neutral barrels.
Name: Dusted Valley 2008 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Fruity, sweet, a touch rubbery, and very much what you should expect from a good, ready, well-made Garnacha from Aragón. The palate is lush and full, with snappy blackberry, raspberry and plum flavors. Round on the finish, with size and texture. Drink now through 2012.
Name: Monfil 2009 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Sweet, ripe, rich and a little baked on the bold bouquet, with a good mouthfeel, layered blackberry and plum fruit, and then a long, robust and clean finish. As value-priced Garnacha from Spain goes, this is on the dot.
Name: Viñedos y Bodegas Pablo 2008 Menguante Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Full, sweet, a touch reduced and granular on the nose, but exemplary of what affordable Garnacha from a good vintage should be like. The palate is stacked and deep, while the flavors are a mix of wild berry, rubber, toast and espresso. Turns a bit hot on the finish, but food will tame that. Drink now.
Name: Lelia 2009 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Nice violet and minerally aromas mix with sweet berry scents, and right then you know you have a competent, correct Garnacha on your hands. It's a bit acidic and bouncy, but the flavors of berry and plum are firm, tasty and fade well on the finish. A fresh and zesty wine for near-term drinking.
Name: Bodegas Virgen del Águila 2009 ia Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Fresh and fruity on the nose, and inviting for what it is: a basic Garnacha with color, spirit and lots of blackberry and plum flavors. The palate is tight and rubbery, but overall this is a fine value despite its short, simple finish.
Name: Monastir 2008 Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Happily, each new vintage of Bésoleil is a bit larger than the previous year, so more people can taste what a joy this wine is. In 2008 it's 82% Grenache, 9% Syrah and 9% Mourvèdre. As with all the Betz wines, it is intensely aromatic. The wine glass fairly explodes with scents of grape, plum, raspberry and cherry. In the mouth grace notes offer hints of leaf and fresh herb. Plush and irresistible.
Name: Betz Family 2008 Bésoleil Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Description: A lovely, miniscule-production Mendocino Grenache, made from certified-organic grapes grown on the old vines of Testa Vineyard, some of the oldest organic vines in the North Coast. The result is a surprisingly bright, lively, fine-drinking Grenache, just as it should be, with lots of juicy cranberry and red fruit on the palate and the bones to age. A tiny bit tight when first opened, it opens up quickly and deliciously.
Name: Horse & Plow 2009 Testa Vineyard Grenache (Mendocino)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Description: This is starting to develop some secondary fruit aromas, richly suggestive of fresh-baked strawberry tarts, with a hint of the Cayuse funk underscoring the complexity. Penetrating and dense, this is both powerful and elegant, with precision and pungency. The liquid minerality provides a firm foundation and elevates the texture. This is a unique style of Grenache, that ripens slowly into a lingering finish with dried herbs and tanned leather.
Name: Cayuse 2007 God Only Knows Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This Armada vineyard (Cayuse) Grenache has got the funk, the terroir of the Rocks, and a spicy/herbal component that shines through. The depth and detail are amazing, and there is plenty of the Cayuse funk—it's a love it or hate it flavor, but it is unique and complex. Has 10% Syrah is in the blend.
Name: K Vintners 2007 The Boy Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Stillwater Creek may prove to be one of the great Grenache sites in Washington, which is experiencing a state-wide renaissance with the grape. This is a stellar effort, bursting with juicy red fruit, bourbon barrel, candied cherries, and a finishing layer of sweet chocolate. Though it bursts onto the palate with a rainbow of fruit flavor, it persists and shows both depth and length as well. Lovely.
Name: Novelty Hill 2007 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Big and juicy, this full throttle Grenache screams across the palate with a load of spicy cherry, brambly berry, and bourbon-soaked plum flavors. Tannins are toasty and the finish leaves a pleasingly bitter coffee impression.
Name: McCrea Cellars 2008 Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Montsant, Catalonia, Spain
Description: Not a lot of glaring aromas of a sweet wine here; in fact, it's showing fresh tomato, cherry and more dryness on the nose than candy or syrup. The palate is tight and a little clipped, with sweet cassis and reduced black plum flavors. Short on the finish, but good and grabby overall.
Name: Agricola Falset-Marca 2007 Ètim Varema Tardana Negre Grenache (Montsant)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This 100% Grenache is young and grapy, flavorful and forward. This has more muscle and depth than might be expected from such young vines. There is a strong streak of grapefruit/ pineapple citrus that elevates and adds some nervous energy to the finish.
Name: Darby 2008 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Very smooth with youthful, juicy, fragrant berry aromas along with a bouncy palate full of sweet cherry and cassis flavors. Clean, snappy, alert and healthy. More simple and straightforward than complex, but worth the money and then some.
Name: Aletta 2008 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This bright and fruity take on the southern Rhône grape is packed with fresh, tangy raspberry flavor, tight and balanced.
Name: Olsen Estates 2008 Vineyard Select Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A perfectly solid Garnacha with pepper, bright red fruit and a touch of country style to the bouquet despite its pedestrian price. The palate is bright and tastes of plum and red berry, while the feel is good and the finish fruity and lively. What inexpensive red wine should be.
Name: Crucillon 2009 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A bit flat and jammy on the nose, and then it runs hot and heavy across the palate, where the flavors waver between citric and plum-cherry. There's a lot of fruit here, but also some burn and finally a dull hum to the finish.
Name: Tienen Duende 2009 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Rioja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Powerful and raisiny on the nose, with asphalt, char and cassis. The palate is saturated and sweet, with flavors of black raisin, plum and blackberry. Staunch on the finish, with licorice and blackness. Solid, strong Garnacha. Drink now through 2012.
Name: Dinastía Vivanco 2007 Colección Vivanco Parcelas de Garnacha  (Rioja)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A little on the heavy, sweet and full side, but that's made up for via true berry and citrus flavors, a clean mouthfeel, and just enough vital acidity. First takes signal a full and ripe-styled rosé with a slight sugary cloy, but there's also depth of flavor and more complexity than many wines of this price offer.
Name: Ochoa 2009 Rosado Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Remarkably well balanced for a wine at nearly 16% alcohol, this is also quite fragrant and complex, boasting an array of scents ranging from slightly mushroomy, savory notes through dried flowers and baking spices. The texture is wonderfully lush and supple, while the flavors add fruit sweetness to the savory components. Long on the finish. Drink now–2015.
Name: R Wines 2007 Chateau Chateau Pergola Blewitt Springs Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: Blewitt + Grenache + 2007 = something magical, to judge from the two offerings tasted for this report. Clarendon Hills's bottling is dense and powerful yet doesn't lose its way. Potent plum pudding and spice cake notes offer plenty of complexity and richness, without excessive weight. Long and slightly warming on the finish. Drink now–2017.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2007 Blewitt Springs Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Starts off with intriguing aromas of coffee, clove and plum that segue into dark, warming flavors. It's full bodied, lush and almost creamy in texture, with supple tannins that only hint at their presence before fading into a long, licorice-tinged finish. Best now–2013.
Name: The Old Faithful 2005 Northern Exposure Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Excellent Garnacha in very modern dressing. The nose is sweet, candied, lightly baked and rich, with hints of prune, coconut and fine aged cheese. The palate is smooth and deep, with blackberry, molasses and licorice flavors. Sturdy and studly wine, with weight and only a pinch of heat and bite. Six hundred cases produced; drink now–2012.
Name: Alto Moncayo 2007 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Barossa, South Australia, Australia
Description: So supple and lush that it appears to demand early drinking, the Moppa Block Grenache also features enough spice and leather to give it the requisite complexity in its youth. Plummy fruit turns a bit chocolaty on the long finish.
Designation: Hand Picked Single Site Moppa Block
Name: Yalumba 2006 Hand Picked Single Site Moppa Block Grenache (Barossa)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Potent, deep and lush, with minty aromas and a lot more wild berry and tobacco than anything crisp or piquant. The palate is lush and packed full of ripe berry and black plum, while the finish is spirited, ripe, full and lusty. A rich, dark style of wine for modern palates. Ready now and over the next two years.
Name: Bodegas Ateca 2007 Atteca Armas Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Smoky, toasty and rich, with no shortage of power and fire in the hole. The palate is meaty and dense, with black fruit, black pepper and heat. But even with the unavoidable heat the wine shows balance along with attractive finishing flavors of fig, beef jerky, licorice and chocolate. Undeniably big and powerful at 16.5% alcohol. Drink soon, and with food. Otherwise it might seem too hot and burning.
Name: Alto Moncayo 2007 Aquilon Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: The rare Australian Grenache you might consider cellaring for more than a couple of years, the 2007 Romas features dark, plummy fruit accented with hints of coffee and chocolate. It's full bodied and richly textured without being overly astringent, with a long finish. Drink 2012–2020.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2007 Romas Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Smoky, roasted and spicy on the nose, with berry fruit, licorice and black pepper scents. Definitely a warm, ripe, chunky wine with smooth blackberry, chocolate and mocha flavors. Big and with plenty of oak, but the integration and overall balance are commendable. Best now through 2012.
Name: Alto Moncayo 2007 Veraton Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: From vines planted more than a century ago, this is dark-fruited Grenache that features hints of mint or camphor alongside ample spice. It's full bodied and supple-textured, round in the mouth without being overblown, finally finishing with a touch of alcoholic warmth. Seems ready to go now–2015.
Name: Torbreck 2006 Les Amis Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Tres Picos, or Three Peaks, ranks as a go-to wine for fans of round, smooth, slightly oaky reds. The bouquet is all mocha and smoky/oaky richness, while the sticky, rich palate deals blackberry and chewy, rooty medicinality. Oaky and spicy late, with licorice and warmth. The best thing is that it's not heavy or overextracted despite being youthful and modern in style.
Name: Borsao 2008 Tres Picos Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Fair warning: the alcohol level on this wine reaches 18.6%, which really can't help but be felt. It does deliver an impressive array of cherry, plum, chocolate and spice complexity, just don't expect it to age gracefully given its tenuous balance.
Name: R Wines 2007 Chateau Chateau Island Ebenezer Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Immediately this wine stands out from most Aragón-region Garnachas. It's deep and poised, with smoky blackberry aromas. The palate is deftly woven, saturated and meaty but also creamy and smooth, with mocha and controlled tannins. Freshness is not lost despite its modern, clean power. Drink now through 2013.
Name: Pagos del Moncayo 2008 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: For those who value a totally natural, biodynamic, unfiltered wine, this is it. The neck of the bottle is lined with purple sediment that is almost psychedelic it's so intense. The wine is fermented with native yeasts, and it's a scrapey, authentic beast of a Grenache, with 15% Syrah in the blend, and it takes no prisoners. Grapey, full-throttle, deep and concentrated, with blueberries and plums, boysenberries and kirsch, it invites both contemplation and hedonistic pleasure.
Name: Cowhorn 2008 Grenache 74 Grenache (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: The 2007 Clarendon is in a more feminine, approachable style than Roman Bratasiuk's other 2007 Grenaches, featuring dried spices, watermelon and cherry aromas and fine—almost delicate—tannins. Cherry-berry flavors finish with hints of cinnamon and clove. Drink now–2015.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2007 Clarendon Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Rather subdued in fruit on the nose, showing more vanilla and toast, but this really expands on the palate, delivering great fruit sweetness and nuance in a harmoniously round, supple package. Finishes long, warm and spicy at 15.5% alcohol.
Name: R Wines 2007 Marquis Philips G.G. Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Superripe fruit, befitting a hot year, suggests early consumption may be the best option for this supple, luscious wine. There's bits of spicy, leathery complexity to go with the intense black cherry fruit. Drink now–2013.
Name: Rocland Estate 2008 Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: The nose of this wine features some delicately lifted floral scents, but also darker notes of brandied cherries and asphalt. Give it some breathing time to let the tarry notes fade and allow the red cherry and cinnamon red-hot flavors to emerge. Finishes long, mouthwatering and just a touch warming. Drink now–2014.
Name: D'Arenberg 2007 The Derelict Vineyard Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Deep and earthy smelling, with meatiness, black fruit and hickory notes to the bouquet. The wine offers concentration and thickness, with ripe, slightly medicinal flavors of plum and blackberry. The same goes for the finish, and overall this is a medium-to-full Grenache that gets it done.
Name: Quo 2008 Old Vines Grenache (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Barossa, South Australia, Australia
Description: Tri-Centenary refers to the fact that these vines have lived in parts of three centuries, being planted prior to 1901. The 2006 isn't the most profoundly complex of recent vintages, but instead offers remarkably pure essences of cherries and berries, allied to a wonderfully silky texture that makes it awfully easy to drink.
Designation: Hand Picked Single Site Tri-Centenary Vineyard Vine Vale
Name: Yalumba 2006 Hand Picked Single Site Tri-Centenary Vineyard Vine Vale Grenache (Barossa)

Appellation: Somontano, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Sweet and full of raspberry aromas, foresty scents and sandalwood. Overall it's a well-made, intriguing Grenache with a fleshy, sturdy body and deep cherry, berry and chocolate flavors. It's a bit tannic, but that only helps the structure. Finishes nicely, with dry spice and vanilla notes.
Name: Viñas del Vero 2007 La Miranda de Secastilla Garnacha (Somontano)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: A big, burly, concentrated Grenache, Yangarra's High Sands bottling seems capable of evolving nicely over the next 3–5 years, although it is supple enough to drink now. Black cherry preserves gain structure on the finish in the form of finely dusty tannins.
Name: Yangarra Estate Vineyard 2006 High Sands Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Clare Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: This superripe Grenache is supple and mouthfilling, coating the palate with an array of chocolate and cola richness. Some peppery, cinnamon-like aromas add a touch of nuance, but overall the impression is of slipping into an overstuffed chair that's comfortable at first but lacks the support for a long-term stay.
Name: Kilikanoon 2007 Prodigal Grenache (Clare Valley)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A steal for six bucks; the nose is floral and black, but under control. Meanwhile, the palate is bouncy, round and balanced, with juicy black plum and wild berry flavors. Clean and solid.
Name: Borsao 2009 Viña Borgia Grenache (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Hints at cedar, spice and dark fruit on the nose, then turns unexpectedly tart on the palate. The tannins are soft, leaving the acidity to provide a counterbalance to the ripe fruit. Drink now.
Name: D'Arenberg 2008 The Custodian Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Clarendon, South Australia, Australia
Description: The 2007 Hickinbotham features attractive scents of ground spices, leather and red cherries, but doesn't seem to have the richness and depth of CH's other Grenaches this year. Tart cherry-berry fruit fades into finely textured tannins on the finish. Drink now–2015.
Name: Clarendon Hills 2007 Hickinbotham Grenache (Clarendon)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: For all this wine's ripeness and heat (16% abv), the aromas are surprisingly delicate, offering up strawberry and raspberry fruit compote. It's full in body, with supple tannins, hints of chocolate and touches of spice and warmth on the finish. Drink now.
Name: R Wines 2008 Marquis Philips Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: This Grenache-based wine includes 10% Tempranillo, 4% Malbec and 2% Syrah in the sophisticated blend. Recently bottled, it's still tight, tannic, and hiding much of its fruit. The aromas give an indication of what's to come—cranberry fruit and lemony acidity, with some firm tannins.
Name: Abacela 2008 Garnacha (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Minty black cherry aromas give it a solid opening, but there's also some mild cleanser and paint scents to the nose. The palate is basic, snappy, fresh and carries good weight, while the flavors are sweet, berry-oriented and softened by vanilla. A good Grenache with good balance.
Name: Bodegas Ateca 2008 Atteca Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: The opening of smoke, rubber and black cherry comes across as being dark and good. The palate holds form with lively cherry, plum and currant flavors and finally a medium-long, somewhat warm and meaty finish. Good for an everyday, no-frills Garnacha.
Name: Bodegas y Vinedos del Jalón 2008 Viña Alarba Old Vines Grenache (Calatayud)

Appellation: Montsant, Catalonia, Spain
Description: More basic and strained than prior wines from this producer. The nose is rubbery and cheesy at first, with leather and blackberry. Hard, tannic and acidic as well, and only a little softer with airing. Flavors are of snappy, tough cherry and berry, and the finish shows tannic bite. Could improve some with aging; now it's a tough go.
Name: Agricola Falset-Marca 2007 Ètim Old Vines Grenache (Montsant)

Appellation: La Mancha, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Kicks off with minty coconut aromas and prune, then a hint of creamy green. The palate shows proper acidity and tannin balance, so the framing for the wine's raspberry flavors is good. Grabby but fresh on the finish, with just enough grapey richness.
Name: Finca Antigua 2007 Garnacha (La Mancha)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Here's another good value red from Borsao. It's about as potent and packed a wine as you'll find for $7, and while it's jumpy, young and aggressive, it's also full of jammy black fruit, sticky extraction and firm tannins. A classic mouthfiller with spunk, color and heft.
Name: Borsao 2009 Monte Oton Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Barossa, South Australia, Australia
Description: A decent introduction to Australian Grenache, a bit simple and one-dimensionally cherry-fruited but clean, supple and easy to drink despite plenty of body, with just a bit of warmth on the finish. Drink now.
Name: R Wines 2008 Bitch Grenache (Barossa)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Clean, fruity and snappy, with pointed red fruit aromas and flavors as well as higher than normal acidity. Tastes fresh and forward and entirely straightforward, with a hollow but easy finish and mild but controlled sharpness.
Name: Bodegas y Vinedos del Jalón 2008 Los Pinos Old Vines Grenache (Calatayud)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: For a higher-priced wine, this has some issues. The nose is heavy and murky, with leathery, baked aromas. In the mouth, it's somewhat choppy and acidic, thus punctuating the cherry tomato portion of the earth-and-leather flavor profile. Lingering oak accents the finish, which is zesty and leans toward sour.
Name: Dominio Lasierpe 2007 Flor de Lasierpe Viñas Viejas Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra del Bajo Aragón, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rusty in hue, with mature, slightly old aromas of leather, gym bag, dried leaves and mature berry. The palate has depth and concentration, while the flavors are herbal and run toward baked black cherry and tobacco. Caramel and mature fruit flavors vie for control of the roasted finish.
Name: Bodegas Tempore 2005 Viña Centuria Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra del Bajo Aragón)
Region: Vino de la Tierra del Bajo Aragón

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Aromas of pine, rubber and rhubarb are austere, and so is the rest of the wine. The palate is run by acidity, which is sharp and scouring. Flavors are tart and underdone, with pie cherry and red raspberry. Sheering but admittedly cleansing, with surprising sourness.
Name: Cruz de Piedra 2007 Capricho Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Starts with tough, almost harsh green aromas on the nose, but with time it settles on herbs and tobacco. The palate is fresh but a touch spiky and grabby, with herbal plum and berry flavors. Solid mouthfeel and length make it worthwhile even if it's herbal and slightly green tasting.
Name: Castillo de Monjardin 2008 La Cantera Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Begins with pasty, lactic aromas and heavy fruit. The palate is both big and clumsy, with sharp acidity amid bulk leading to choppy plum and medicinal cherry flavors. A clacky wine with power but not much finesse.
Name: Bodegas la Casa de Lúculo 2008 Jardín de Lúcolo Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Neon purple in color, young and jumpy, but hey, that's what simple Garnacha from this part of Spain is all about. Expect fruity, jammy aromas and a blazing, full-fruited palate of rubber, black fruits and bacon. It's grapey but honest, and for the price it's as expected.
Name: Garnacha de Fuego 2009 Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Almansa, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Mint, carob and green-tinged fruit aromas precede an herbal-tasting palate with olive-influenced plum, berry and cola flavors. From down south in Spain, it shows pretty good body and an okay mouthfeel, but the flavor profile is a little funky and strange.
Name: Bodegas Piqueras 2008 Castillo de Almansa Tintorera Garnacha (Almansa)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra del Bajo Aragón, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A green, struggling wine from front to back. The nose kicks up underripe aromas to go with distant red fruit, while the palate is edgy and prickly, with high acidity creating snappy cherry and green flavors.
Name: Bodegas y Vinos de Lécera NV Esenzia Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra del Bajo Aragón)
Region: Vino de la Tierra del Bajo Aragón

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: There is a bit of sweetness which gives a quick impression of body to the light, cherry-flavored fruit. Once in the mouth the wine quickly fades, leaving just an astringent aftertaste with no particular varietal character.
Name: Agate Ridge 2008 Grenache (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Fragrant and spicy, this opens with green pepper notes and boatloads of prickly/brambly raspberry/strawberry fruit. From a cool vintage, the blend includes 15% Syrah. It's nicely handled, with great penetration and a dancer's precision.
Name: Maison Bleue 2008 Alder Ridge Vineyard La Montagnette Grenache (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This high-acid, intense wine is beautifully aromatic, with piercing and tart flavors of cranberry and raspberry, pure and laced with minerality. Terrific penetration, the persistence of wet stone, citrus, raspberry and cranberry flavors is impressive.
Name: Maison Bleue 2008 Boushey Vineyard Le Midi Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Originally intended as a blending grape for the Tempranillo, this is now being separately bottled. The Alder Ridge Grenache is blended with 20% Syrah. It's a ripe, almost liquorous wine, with some alcoholic heat. Nonetheless, the Gramercy style, with an emphasis on acidity and minerality, along with tart red fruit flavors, comes through.
Name: Gramercy 2007 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Clare Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: A top-notch effort, The Duke (a single-vineyard bottling) offers lovely cherry fruit, full body allied to a wonderfully silky texture and tremendous length. What's not to like? Drink it over the next 3–4 years.
Name: Kilikanoon 2006 The Duke Grenache (Clare Valley)

Appellation: Clare Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Full and round in the mouth, this lacks the dynamic purity and luxurious texture of its pricier stablemate, The Duke, but it's still an excellent wine that blends black cherry and strawberry fruit with just a touch of spice. Drink now–2011.
Name: Kilikanoon 2006 Prodigal Grenache (Clare Valley)

Appellation: Clare Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Very ripe, with brandied cherries and dark chocolate combining on the palate. May be too much for some people, but the wine's roundness and soft, silky texture are undeniably appealing. Drink now.
Name: Reilly's 2006 Old Bushvine Grenache (Clare Valley)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Very sweet and rich, and probably a little too much so for some folks. Aromas of cassis, berry liqueur and black fruit candy are sweet, sweet, sweet, but after the sugary richness subsides you do get a dark, brooding, mammoth Garnacha with prune, chocolate and baked power. A 15.5% heavyweight to drink before 2011.
Name: Bodegas Ateca 2006 Atteca Armas Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Somontano, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A sweet, raisiny old-vines Garnacha with candied aromas and a fat, chunky body that houses soft, short black fruit and peppery flavors. Tastes like licorice candy on the finish, which brings some heat and burn as well. An interesting Grenache that is sweet but isn't over the top in terms of ripeness.
Name: Viñas del Vero 2005 Secastilla Grenache (Somontano)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Darker and earthier than most basic Garnachas, with aromas of compost, baked earth, crusty black fruits and leather. The palate has a nice, ripe, bodied feel, while flavors of blackberry and boysenberry bring just the slightest hint of herbal green. Toasty and solid on the finish.
Name: El Burro 2008 Kickass Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rusty in color, with initial aromas of smoke, dried leaves, herbs, tobacco and subtle berry. That all indicates that it's not overdone, and thus the tobacco, earth and dried fruit flavors are par for the course. Dry and leafy on the finish, which indicates that now is the time to get at it.
Name: Pagos Familia Langa 2006 Real de Aragón Centenaria Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Standard black-cherry aromas carry a candied, vanilla-like twinge, while the feel is juicy and snappy. Flavors of sweet berries and cherry are just fine, and they come with a nod of spice and bitterness. Punchy and fresh overall, with good ripeness and balance.
Name: Castillo de Monséran 2008 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Concentrated, willing aromas of black cherry and sweet plum are nice and friendly, while the palate is lively, juicy and a little tart for Garnacha, with an emphasis on red raspberry. The wine dries out a bit on the finish, leaving vanilla and spice. Good enough for a basic Aragonese red.
Name: Grandes Vinos y Viñedos 2006 Corona d'Aragón Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Light to medium aromas of cherry and berry are fresh and snappy, while the palate has high acidity, light extract and crisp, almost lean flavors of cherry and red plum. A pointed but clean wine that will do well with simple foods like sliced ham or salami.
Name: Manyana 2008 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Rubber and plum aromas are accented by cinnamon spice notes on this fuller-sized, somewhat sticky but basic Garnacha. Dark in color and slightly herbal in terms of flavors, with tart cherry and a slightly dilute feel to the finish. Basic but honest.
Name: Legado Muñoz 2008 Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A little burnt and leathery smelling, with stem, bramble and raspberry aromas. The palate is sheering and tight, with semisharp acidity enlivening herbal, peppery red fruit flavors. As a whole, there isn't a lot of substance here to weigh.
Name: Viña Paquita 2008 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Funky smelling and unfamiliar, with sweet, candied spice notes and strange candied cherry aromas. Vibrant and bouncy in terms of feel, but follows the nose by tasting sweet and weird. Weak on the finish as well.
Name: Bodegas Navarro López 2008 Rojo Granrojo Garnacha (Tierra de Castilla)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Jammy, sweet and extremely raisiny, with a nose that matches the palate. Low in acid, so low in pulse. Pruney on the finish and seemingly overripe. Not well balanced.
Name: Agustín Cubero 2006 Stylo Old Vines Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A fuller, more minty and deep Garnacha than Hughes' Lot 129. This has standup, standout aromas followed by deep berry fruit flavors. It has plenty of body but keeps its balance, and the finish is thick and strong. A little rugged but really good by regional standards.
Name: Cameron Hughes 2007 Lot 128 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This is nothing more than a few barrels of wine bottled by Hughes, a so-called “global vintner.” And like its Lot 128 brother, it is really good juice. Inky and floral, with blueberry and wild raspberry flavors. It's smooth, fresh, bold and finishes with mint and chocolate. Shows the positives of Campo de Borja's Garnacha.
Name: Cameron Hughes 2007 Lot 129 Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Starts with hard aromas akin to nail polish and rubber gloves. More typical and fruity in the mouth, but it remains kind of lean despite being expansive in the mouth. Tastes like raspberry, with some candy. Gets better as it airs out.
Name: Quo 2007 Old Vines Grenache (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Full, savory and beefy on the nose, with a snappy, juicy palate that's flavorful and offers pretty good feel. Size is no issue with this wine, which gives you all the basics of red wine while never once hinting at being more than it is.
Name: Bodega Virgen de la Sierra 2007 La Brujo Roble Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Vivid pink in color, with dusty, easygoing raspberry aromas. The palate is a bit soft and low in acidity, which indicates that this is the year to drink the wine...and as soon as possible. Flavors of cherry and strawberry are regular, if a touch bitter toward the finish.
Name: Casita Mami 2009 Rosado Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Grenache is not an easy grape to ripen in Washington, but this is just about perfect—juicy with fresh berry and rhubarb fruit, and added notes of marjoram, rosemary and cracked pepper. Full-bodied and pushing close to 15% alcohol, this is fine pizza wine.
Name: Dusted Valley 2007 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Though it's Grenache, you can't really tell from the flavors. This is similar to many ice wines from western Canada—a bit fat and unctuous for icewine, tasting of caramel, simple and sweet.
Name: Gilbert Cellars 2008 Ice Wine Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: On the spot and sweet, with black cherry and roundness on the nose. Plays above its price league via ripe plum and berry flavors, bounce, body and build. Whole, concentrated and shows good structure, depth and character. About as good as inexpensive Garnacha gets.
Name: Borsao 2008 Monte Oton Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Floral, sweet and not the least bit complicated or strained. This is easygoing red wine for easy times. It's a bit candied and baked, but that's Garnacha from Central Spain. Decently balanced and sturdy, especially given the price tag.
Name: Viña Borgia 2008 Grenache (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Kaesler's Grenache features wonderfully perfumed aromas of dried spices and cherries, but winds up a little thin on the palate, offering little more than crisp, bright watermelony fruit. Drink up.
Name: Kaesler 2006 The Fave Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Smells like bath soap, then turns grassy and burnt. Tannic and medicinal in the mouth, although better as it airs out. Tastes and feels overdone and super sweet.
Designation: El Chaparral de Vega Sindoa Old Vines
Name: Vega Sindoa 2008 El Chaparral de Vega Sindoa Old Vines Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The Grenache is blended with 10% Syrah and 5% Mourvèdre. It's showing well, spicy and forward, with tangy plum and cherry fruit, finishing with a light chocolate note and a hint of garrigue.
Name: Chatter Creek 2008 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A little heat on the nose is acceptable given that the remaining cherry and plum aromas are pure. A bit acidic on the palate but staunchly fresh, with good fruit flavor in the red plum category. Cleansing due to higher acidity, with hints of mocha and mineral.
Name: Quo 2008 Grenache (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Racy red wine, with mild bramble and brine aromas to go with spunky cherry-plum flavors. Quite zesty, bright and juicy, but solidly put together and not overly acidic. Even shows a distant chocolaty side, which is not uncommon for young Garnacha.
Name: Bodegas Aragonesas 2008 Cinco Josés - 5 Joes Old Vine Garnacha (Campo de Borja)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Starts with clean but basic cherry/berry aromas, but with a candied twist. The palate is more lean and sharp than ideal, with zippy red fruit flavors that carry some scour. Lively and peppy, but a little sharp in the long run.
Name: Grandes Vinos y Viñedos 2008 D'Aragon Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Green and lean Garnacha, with tobacco, celery and other vegetal aromas. Chunky in the mouth, but rather sour tasting, with grassy, green fruit and bite. Not a prime-time player.
Name: Bodega Virgen de la Sierra 2007 Condesa de Sarabella Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This new release of Bésoleil is 80% Grenache; 5% Syrah and 15% Mourvèdre. Intensely aromatic, bursting with black cherry, strawberry and raspberry aromas, its luscious palate is replete with black fruits. There are streaks of tree bark, a whiff of smoke and above all intensity of fruit.
Name: Betz Family 2007 Bésoleil Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: This sharp, acidic Garnacha is the latest expansion of Abacela's Iberian explorations. Grapey and young, with strawberry fruit and a lick of anise, it's still quite tight and should improve with additional bottle age.
Name: Abacela 2007 Garnacha (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Red-fruit aromas are a little candied and medicinal, but that's common with young Garnacha. Zesty and racy in the mouth, but there's enough body and fruit to keep it right. Flavors of cherry and raspberry are correct, and the rubbery finish holds steady.
Name: Viña Alarba 2007 Old Vines Grenache (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Red fruit aromas are a bit pickled and brambly, while the palate is piquant and spiky in acids. Strawberry, rhubarb and cranberry flavors finish reedy and brambly like the nose.
Name: Bodega Virgen de la Sierra 2007 Albada Viñas Viejas Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Dark in color, with candied cherry and cola aromas. The rest of the road is bumpy, with black, sweet fruit and green juniper flavors. Herbal and minty on the finish.
Name: Bodegas la Casa de Lúculo 2007 Cátulo Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Rioja, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Awfully bright and forward on the nose, but then tart, sheering and grating on the palate, with acidic raspberry flavors. Scratchy, edgy red wine. Fresh but that's where it ends.
Name: Bodegas Valdemar 2007 Conde de Valdemar  (Rioja)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The first Grenache from Novelty Hill, this explodes from the glass with aromas of Bourbon-soaked cherries, fragrant and seductive. In the mouth the wine is tart and tastes of cranberry, strawberry and black cherry candy, with a whiff of smoke. Lovely fruit, tangy acid and surprising concentration for such young vines.
Name: Novelty Hill 2006 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is an odd color, plum tinged with orange; two different bottles looked exactly alike. At first it showed a dusty, slightly dirty flavor, and some reductive rubbery scents. But it opened up and became plummier, round, still with a dusty, dried-wood character.
Name: Alexandria Nicole 2007 Grenache (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Egypt, Egypt
Description: Ripe pear, apple and tropical fruit in the nose leads into easy-drinking yellow fruit flavors on the palate. Creamy with a clean finish—a great everyday sip that will pair well with poultry, salads, cheeses.
Name: Sahara Vineyards 2008 Caspar Blanc de Noirs Grenache (Egypt)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This tasty rosé is a creative blend of 75% Grenache and 25% Viognier. They complement each other well, making a round, full-bodied wine that is not heavy, with fresh fruit flavors.
Name: Cougar Crest 2007 Rosé Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Salinic smelling, with a spot of nectarine on the nose. The palate is full and chunky, with thick plum and raspberry flavors that fail to refresh. Tastes pithy and mildly bitter on the finish.
Name: Volteo 2008 Rosé Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Controlled, expressive and impressive for Garnacha. Dark fruit and dark spice are the lead actors, while the supporting cast includes a lush feel and good length. Frankly this is a delicious, well-made Garnacha that pours on the black fruit and brown sugar. Dense and balanced from start to finish.
Name: Viñedos y Bodegas Pablo 2004 Gran Viu Garnacha del Terreno Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This is Scottish winemaker Norrel Robertson's unoaked, straightforward Garnacha. It has mildly stemmy, all-natural aromas followed by zesty red-fruit flavors, herbal accents and a quick, acid-washed palate and finish. There's ample body and power, and fresh, candied red-fruit character.
Name: El Escocés Volante 2007 El Puño Bareknuckle Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Here's a bright, forward, no-issues Garnacha that shows the upside of Calatayud and the grape in general. It's a touch raw and racy, but otherwise it's a nice wine with forward cherry flavors and a lightly charred, earthy finish. Pointed and racy, which is what you want from Spanish Garnacha.
Name: El Escocés Volante 2007 La Multa La Revancha Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Barossa, South Australia, Australia
Description: Despite exceeding 1% residual sugar, this rosé only seems sweet on the finish. Otherwise, it delivers bright cherry fruit in a plump, mouth-filling wine, turning to slight stoniness on the finish. Imported by The Country Vintner.
Name: Loose End 2007 Rosé Grenache (Barossa)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Nice black cherry, cracked pepper and a slight wave of perfume make the nose attractive, while the palate is bright and a touch sharp with red-fruit flavors. Cherry, red plum and gentle spice notes work the finish, and overall the wine seems honest and well made.
Name: Valcantara 2008 Old Vine Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A touch green and grassy at the start, with cinnamon, cherry candy and red-fruit aromas. The palate is fresh and snappy, with sweet berry flavors and just a slight bit of resin and/or green character. Finishes light and quick, making it an easygoing red wine that isn't meant for deep analysis.
Name: Lelia 2008 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: The nose is heavy and dosed with burnt rubber and leather, but the palate fares better, with cherry and raspberry flavors and a pretty clean and clear mouthfeel. A simple but sound wine with a slight resiny green character but mostly it shows decent red fruit with mild sweetness. Imported by Freixenet USA.
Name: Tapeña 2007 Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Char-accented wild berry and plum aromas go straight into a bright, edgy palate of cherry and plum, and overall this is a simple, slightly candied Garnacha that has some sizzle and burn to it. Racy and the slightest bit green at its core.
Name: Pagos Familia Langa 2007 Real de Aragon Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: With basic pear, green melon and other sweet aromas, the nose is controlled. But the palate on this white Garnacha is dry and soda-like, with seltzer-like flavors touched up by citrus. Decent but bland. Imported by Frontier Wine Imports.
Name: Viñedos y Bodegas Pablo 2008 Menguante Garnacha Blanca Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Rhubarb and brambly black cherry aromas set up sweet, candied, fairly forced red-berry flavors that have a green element and a slightly cloying feel. The palate has some weight and creaminess to it, but also the sugary feel you get when eating cotton candy.
Name: Bodegas Navarro López 2007 Rojo Granrojo Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Small amounts of Mourvèdre, Syrah, Counoise and Cinsault add complexity to this excellent Grenache, grown at the Ciel du Cheval vineyard on Red Mountain. Supple and aromatic, it expresses itself with ripe, sweet strawberry and black cherry fruit, whiffs of pepper and pencil lead, and a full-bodied midpalate that continues cleanly through a lingering finish.
Name: McCrea Cellars 2007 Grenache (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Its flavors are right up front, rich and earthy. The grapes have been farmed biodynamically, and the wine has a potent mix of ripe plum, fig, balsamic, coffee and compost flavors. It is concentrated and sharp, with a tense, resinous spine.
Name: K Vintners 2006 The Boy Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Minervois La Liviniere, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
Description: A beautiful opaque garnet color, you know this wine is going to be intense at first glance. Dark rich fruits abound on the nose and palate: blueberry, black plum, violet, coffee granules and a hint of cured meat. The mouth is silky and full and beautifully supported by soft, dusty tannins. Closes on a long, hearty finish.
Name: Château Maris 2006 Old Vine Grenache (Minervois La Liviniere)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: A fresh and fruity Grenache, seemingly designed with summer grilling in mind. It's full, round and lush, a bomb of black cherries and chocolate that finishes with supple tannins. Drink now.
Name: Simon Hackett 2006 Old Vine Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Full in the mouth and even a touch syrupy in texture, this Grenache is bursting with ripe cherry fruit that's kirsch-like in its expression and intensity, while subtle spice and dusty earth shadings impart depth and complexity. Drink now.
Name: Tir Na N'og 2006 Old Vines Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: This is a burly, firmly structured Grenache evidently meant to age, which makes it a little tough to evaluate right now. Big black cherry fruit lacks complexity, marked mainly by faint toasted-almond nuances. Try after 2010.
Name: S.C. Pannell 2006 Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Not much different than the basic Sarria rosado, with maybe a touch more concentration and richness. The nose is a bit dusty, with good berry fruit notes and a whiff of cherry blossom. The palate is wet and fresh, with raspberry and plum-skin flavors. Crisp and refreshing.
Name: Señorío de Sarria 2008 Viñedo N° 5 Rosé Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Meaty and composed, with an earthy nose that carries plenty of dark fruit and minty herbal accents. The palate shows clarity and density, but it's a touch gritty, hard and tannic. Flavors of cola, blackberry and burnt toast are masculine, while the finish is also kind of crusty and dark.
Name: Pegaso 2004 Barrancos de Pizarra Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra Ribera del Jiloca, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Berry, earth and a touch of citrus peel make for a good bouquet, while the palate shows structure and lots of verve. The flavor profile of plum, cherry and roasted berry is solid and complete, while the finish is fresh, clean and reaches a proper finale. Call it a well-made but familiar type of old-vines Garnacha.
Name: Vega del Jiloca 2004 Tinta Garnacha (Vino de la Tierra Ribera del Jiloca)
Region: Vino de la Tierra Ribera del Jiloca

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: The 2006 Custodian blends slightly disparate pieces into a harmonious whole. Tart berries accent stewed fruit on the nose, while herbal elements highlight superripe fruit and chocolate on the palate. It's full and round in the mouth, ending a bit soft.
Name: D'Arenberg 2006 The Custodian Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Clean, fresh and layered up front, with peach, cherry and nectarine flavors and then apricot on the finish. The feel is good throughout, with no excess weight or sweetness. An uncomplicated, no-frills rosé, which is what Navarra and Señoría de Sarria do best.
Name: Señorío de Sarria 2008 Rosado Grenache (Navarra)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Light cherry and raspberry aromas take it to a level above neutral, while the palate is just as clean and light, with apricot, peach and strawberry flavors. With some tang and good acidity, it shows freshness and persistence.
Name: Viña Sardasol 2008 Rosado de Lagrima Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Navarra, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Ochoa usually puts out a good rosado made from Garnacha, and this vintage keeps the winery's reputation intact. It starts with fresh peachy aromas and then comes on with light berry and peach flavors. Arguably a bit candied, but perfectly good for summer quaffing.
Name: Ochoa 2008 Rosado Garnacha (Navarra)

Appellation: Currency Creek-McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Shows decent complexity, with smoke, leather and spice notes dominating over modest levels of cranberryish fruit. Either this is beginning to dry out, or it was never all that lush to begin with. Drink up.
Name: Ballast Stone Estate Wines 2004 Grenache (Currency Creek-McLaren Vale)
