Name: Martinez Bujanda 1997 Conde de Valdemar Garnacha Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Calatayud, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Big and fruity, with sugary cherry fruit and a big, aggressive finish. The acidity here is abrasive as it sears your tongue. In the end, you almost feel a shock as you drink this overdone wine that tastes more like a powdered fruit drink than fine wine.
Name: Albada 2000 Garnacha (Calatayud)

Appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
Description: Potent in the nose, with stylish cola and licorice aromas. The palate is super sweet, lush and tasty, with a full blast of black plum, black cherry and chocolate flavors. The tannins are drying and strong, but they intermix with the powerful fruit to create a coffee-like taste and mouthfeel. Very good and gets better with airing. Editors' Choice.
Name: Domaine de Servans 1999 Cuvee Exceptionnelle Grenache (Côtes du Rhône)

Appellation: Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Rhône Valley, France
Description: Mint, chocolate and berry fruit ride high on the nose. The palate is a bit light for CdP, but it's also refreshing, as the wine will drink well with food or if the weather turns a bit warm. The finish offers crisp raspberry flavors and some drying, medium-strength tannins. Well made, with proper acidity and a bit of light, oak-based toast.
Name: Michel Picard 1999 Grenache (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)

Appellation: Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Rhône Valley, France
Description: Light in color, in fact almost transparent. The nose is full of tomato, brier and dried herbs. In a word: it's weak. The palate is equally lean and spicy, while the finish seems starched out and on its final legs. On the plus side is a leathery feel and some dried-herb nuances that mingle below the surface.
Name: Ferraton Père et Fils 1998 Le Parvis Grenache (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)

Appellation: Cariñena, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Full and minty, and quite the bargain at five bucks. This bargain buster features some cherry liqueur and sucking-candy flavors, while the finish is not devoid of some class, as it offers coffee and chocolate notes. Yes, it's a bit like cherry soda without the bubbles, but what's not to like at this price, especially if the menu calls for burgers or London broil? If Two Buck Chuck is so popular, try giving this wine “hug,” the English translation for abrazo. Best Buy.
Name: Abrazo 2001 Garnacha (Cariñena)

Appellation: Gigondas, Rhône Valley, France
Description: Ripe, rich and muscular. The flavors are spicy, a fine mixture of prunes and pepper, while the finish is tight and chalky, offering a fine interplay of tannins and acids. —M.S.
Name: Paul Jaboulet Aîné 1999 Pierre Aiguille  (Gigondas)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: From old head-pruned vines, this full-bodied red wine satisfies despite a certain one-dimensionality. The flavors are rich in cherries, the tannins are thick but fine, and the wine is very dry. It has an attractive suppleness that feels good on the palate.
Name: Yalumba 2000 Bush Vine Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Catalonia, Catalonia, Spain
Description: The Best Buy of the year? The price is unbelievable for what you get: bright, crunchy Grenache fruit that overflows the glass with ripe cherries, capped off by a hint of white pepper on the finish. It's fresh, it's bouncy and it's a bit rambunctious in its exuberant youth—perfect with assertively seasoned hamburgers or meatloaf.
Name: Viña Alarba 2001 Old Vines Grenache (Catalonia)

Appellation: Priorat, Catalonia, Spain
Description: Sweet is the best way to describe the nose, which pushes heavy doses of maple and molasses. The palate's black cherry flavors are clean and forward, but all in all this wine suffers from too much driving acidity. The acids literally sweat the tongue
Name: Castellflorit 1999 Tinto Garnacha (Priorat)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Like many Aussie Grenaches, this is a soft, forward wine that's made for early consumption. But the alcohol is in balance with the juicy cherry fruit and the oak is well integrated, adding dried spices and a hint of chocolate without becoming overpowering. —J.C.
Name: Ross Estate 1999 Old Vine Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Barossa Valley, South Australia, Australia
Description: Rich and intense but also round and soft. A horsey note adds complexity and rusticity to the dark chocolate, leather and black cherry aromas and flavors. —J.C.
Name: Kurtz Family 2000 Boundary Row Grenache (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: A soft, round wine that almost seems designed for glugging. Dusty earth and dried grass aromas give way to a sweet, alcoholic attack filled with red berries and cherries. The warm, spirity finish leaves you glowing and reaching for another sip. —J.C.
Name: Oliverhill 2000 Bradey Block Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Aptly named, for the oak influence here is strong—a dusty woodiness that's almost cedary. Fortunately, it's well integrated with the full-bodied cherry fruit. Finishes dry, but soft and ripe. —J.C.
Name: Twelve Staves 2000 Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Langhorne Creek, South Australia, Australia
Description: This round, soft, alcoholic wine deserves praise for its spicy-peppery warmth and abundant cherry fruit. Those same qualities are also its biggest shortcoming: The low acidity and high alcohol make it seem a bit heavy. —J.C
Name: Temple Bruer 1998 Cornucopia Grenache (Langhorne Creek)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Seems slightly hollow, and finishes with some coarse oak, but the fruit flavors of cherries and yellow-fleshed red plums are pretty and accented by a hint of smoke. Quaffable. —J.C.
Name: Simon Hackett 2000 Old Vine Grenache (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: South Australia, South Australia, Australia
Description: Deceptively light in color, this wine nevertheless packs a wallop, with a hefty 14.5% alcohol. The delicate—almost Burgundian—cherries start off buried by oak and alcohol, but after some airing the flavors come together in a pleasant mélange of Bing cherries, maple syrup and caramel, accented on the finish by a touch of black pepper. Best Buy.
Name: Oxford Landing 1998 Limited Release Grenache (South Australia)

Appellation: McLaren Vale, South Australia, Australia
Description: Sweaty leather and cinnamon notes dress up sour cherry aromas and flavors. Shows nice complexity, folding in sweet spice and plum notes, but finishes with a tart, hard edge.
Name: Twelve Staves 1999 Grenache (McLaren Vale)
